title: Quiz 4: Blood, Lymphatic & Musculoskeletal Disorders
description: Covers haematological disorders like Sickle Cell and Anaemia, plus Orthopaedic conditions like Fractures and Talipes.

questions.question: Which type of Talipes is the most common (95% of cases)?
questions.explanation: Talipes Equinovarus (Clubfoot) is the most common, where the foot is plantar flexed and inverted.

questions.question: Which of the following are known triggers for a Sickle Cell Crisis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hypoxia, dehydration, infection, and strenuous exercise can all trigger sickling. High fluids PREVENT it.
questions.hint: Anything that reduces oxygen or blood flow.

questions.question: In Sickle Cell Anaemia, the red blood cells have a shortened life span of approximately ___BLANK___ days.
questions.explanation: Sickle cells live only about 20 days compared to 120 days for normal RBCs, leading to anaemia.

Order the general principles of fracture management:
questions.explanation: First you fix the break (Reduction), then keep it still (Immobilisation), then get it moving again (Rehabilitation).

questions.question: Burkitt's Lymphoma typically presents with a tumour in the jaw or mandible in children.
questions.explanation: Burkitt's tumour often affects the jaw/mandible, causing loose teeth and deformity.

questions.question: Which drug class prevents HIV from converting RNA into DNA?
questions.explanation: NRTIs (like AZT) prevent the reverse transcription of RNA to DNA.

questions.question: What is the term for a fracture where the bone bends and breaks only partially, common in children?
questions.explanation: Greenstick fractures are incomplete breaks common in children due to softer bones.

questions.question: Based on the image description, identify the condition where the heel is turned INWARDS.

richContent.content: [Image Description: A foot deformity where the heel is tilted towards the midline of the body]

questions.explanation: Varus = Inward turning (towards midline). Valgus = Outward turning.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical features of Leukaemia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Leukaemia causes marrow overcrowding leading to anaemia, bleeding (low platelets), infection (abnormal WBCs), and organ enlargement.
questions.hint: Think of bone marrow failure signs.
